subject: Economics
title: The Economics of Traffic: Why More Lanes Don't Fix Congestion
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Economics of Traffic: Why More Lanes Don't Fix Congestion usable.

hook.text: Los Angeles widened the 405 freeway by adding a lane. Traffic got worse. Houston added 23 lanes to the Katy Freeway.

buildup.text: Induced demand: when you make driving easier, more people drive.

discovery.text: Studies show that a 10% increase in road capacity generates roughly 10% more traffic within a few years.

twist.text: The opposite works too. When Seoul demolished an elevated highway, traffic improved. Fewer roads meant fewer drivers.

climax.text: Building more roads to fix traffic is like loosening your belt to fix obesity.

punchline.text: More lanes don't reduce traffic. They create more of it.

quiz.question: What is 'induced demand' in transportation economics?
options: Expanding road capacity attracts additional traffic that fills the new space
